title: Appraisals 101: What Fix-and-Flip Investors Need to Know
excerpt: Understanding appraisals is crucial for fix-and-flip investors aiming to maximize profits and avoid costly surprises. Learn how appraisals work, what impacts value, and how to leverage appraisal outcomes to your advantage.

content.text: Why Appraisals Matter for Fix-and-Flip Investors

Every property is unique, and values can shift quickly. Appraisals provide an objective, point-in-time estimate of a property's fair market value—essential for buying right, securing financing, and selling for profit.

items: Appraiser researches property details, tax records, and past sales
Requests info like rent rolls or expense statements for income properties
Visits the property to assess condition and features
Compares recent sales of similar properties and adjusts for differences
Delivers a written report with value and supporting data
Signs of damage or deferred maintenance

content.text: Timeline: How Long Does an Appraisal Take?
Expect 1–2 hours onsite for average homes, longer for large properties. The full process (including research and report) typically takes 7–10 days, but can vary based on appraiser workload.

items: Low square footage or few beds/baths
Lack of curb appeal or amenities

content.text: Typical appraisal fees range from $300–$400 for standard homes, up to $600+ in high-value markets, and more for large or complex properties. In purchases, buyers usually pay; in refis, the owner pays.
What Happens If the Appraisal Is Low?

items: Negotiate with the seller to lower the price
Pay the difference out of pocket (appraisal gap)
Back out if you have an appraisal contingency

content.text: How Long Is an Appraisal Good For?
In fast-moving markets, appraisals may only be valid for 30–90 days. In slower markets, they can be good for up to a year. Lenders may have their own requirements.

items: Appraisals are essential for securing financing and selling at top dollar
Accurate property improvements can boost appraised value
Budget for appraisal costs and possible gaps
Know your options if the appraisal comes in low
